text: It's not about the economics. Very little Huawei products (servers, receivers and comm equipment) enters US. This is about what the Intelligence discover about Huawei. Huawei, Lenovo and many Chinese companies are owned or partly owned by PLA (Peoples Liberation Army). I don't know about Huawei but I can tell you Lenovo add Keylogger chips to all their computers sold to Colleges and US Gov't agencies (Via under former name IBM PC).  They use spyware for consumers.  Now Oneplus can sell their phones in US because they have been vetted to not be own by PLA (Too smaller of a company).  One thing all Chinese companies have to abide by is their Chinese National Intelligence Law Article 7, which states ‚Äúobligation of Chinese citizens to support national intelligence work.‚Äù However, ‚Äúit does not authorize pre-emptive spying; national intelligence work must be defensive in nature.‚Äù Example, PLA can order Oneplus to provide all data relevant to any US citizen and the Chinese Gov't will get it because Oneplus is a Chinese company.  As for proof you'll never see proof from US Gov't which will expose method of detection and or source which can harm US methodology if discovered. Huawei will have no problem surviving despite what people think.  OS is not that hard to create.  They can get a free version of Android and integrated with their EMUI and provide their own updates or they can do what Apple has done and use Linux base OS and create their own.  As for hardware they have their own hardware and doesn't require any US companies' hardware and if they need a particular hardware they can copy it just like they did before they became respectable. Just my two cents worth.

text:
I've previously owned iPhone and Samsung phones but I have to admit, from the perspective of watching entertainment on the go, Sony Xperia 1's specifications blow other phones out of the water such as Samsung S10, iPhone XS, One Plus 7 Pro etc. I will definitely be upgrading my phone to Sony Xperia 1.
Let's deal with the FACTS.


- Sony Xperia 1: 10-bit display (meaning it can display just over 1 billion colours) and fully unlock the potential of 100% DCI-P3 + BT2020. 
Competition: 8-bit display (meaning it can display just over 16 million colours). Even if the product has HDR 10+ certification, it cannot unlock the rest of the colours due to the 8-bit display limitation.

Sony Xperia 1: 
- Has 100% DCI-P3 support along with 2020 and D65 White Point to reference better/accurate whites. 
- Each Sony Xperia 1 has been tuned to the Sony OLED Master Monitor which costs approximately ¬£35,000 - ¬£50,000. In an interview with Naoki Matsubara (Sony Display Engineer), he states that while OLED looks beautiful, from a film perspective, it did not have that 'film' tone before calibration hence why they had opted to calibrate it to the Sony OLED Master Monitor.

@KT Chong - America feeds China. China depends on America to feed their people which is why the farmers are upset with the current tariffs although President Trump has stated he would support the farmers during this time.

There is substance to the issue with Huawei and American intelligence. We need to remember there is usually more to something than the public sees and or knows - heck, look at all the hoopla the last few years over the supposed Russian collusion with the Trump campaign that after over 25 million (tax) dollars and a significant number of testimonies was proven to be no collusion with Russia by the Trump campaign BUT Russian involvement was found in the election which is being investigated now along with all the players involved with that.

China has had very high tariffs on America/US which President Trump has been trying to negotiate a more equitable trade deal. At first it was thought that China was interested then backed out. 

This ban is not just about the issues with Huawei and intelligence - which are valid - but also will bring in China most likely as Huawei is a government company, along with put pressure on China as a side note to come to the table to negotiate a trade deal although it most likely will not help Huawei as that is a separate issue.

text: @Michael Smith Creating an operating system out of an existing platform is one thing but copying hardware is not going to be instant.  The money in R&D would be better spent for the time being focusing on staying alive as a company. They still have markets outside of the US and being 100% self reliant would take years and in the tech market in the US it is very unlikely they could recover from that. As far as just throwing together an operating system quickly to save face I doubt that would fair well, look at how windows phones went. That was a very established trusted brand but it was a new concept. I don't foresee windows phones making a comeback anytime soon. With this pretty much tarnishing they're name I don't see any new development happening in the US market right now unless this all goes away really quickly and people are able to forget. Right now I'd imagine they are focussed on damage control and support for their current customers if they are going to keep any shred of their name in tact and maybe trying to move the remainder of the current line of phones not affected in stock. Either way its bad news all around as it cuts completion which lessens incentives and it would be damaging to the progress of the mid tier market that its crucial to getting any kind of decent affordable product with advancement in ingenuity and new features slowing and prices either holding or in some cases still rising in the more established brands. The point is when the government gets involved with limiting  free trade  then there will be negative consequences felt by the consumer in some way and in this case there is a broad spectrum of crossover so the effects will be felt by more.

text:
@Bruce Goldsmith, I agree with you when it comes to software.  It'll take them a while to come up with a decent OS and if they follow what Samsung did with their Tizen, I don't think they'll have any problems.  Samsung sells Z series Smartphones with Tizen with no Android OS attached to it to a smaller market and won't have any problems transitioning over to their flagship if need be. Don't sell Huawei short when it comes to hardware.  They have very minimal time to copy any hardware.  They're still selling counterfeit Cisco Systems, Ericsson, NEC, Juniper Networks, Oracle and so forth to worldwide customers.  I think out of all of them they tailor to their design, the Cisco Systems' network equipment they copied to include flawed OS didn't change much and Cisco corrected the OS on the later models that Huawei don't have.  They're Hq in Shenzen the electronics innovation and hardware counterfeit Capital in the world. If you never been there you'll never know how good they're really are at electronics counterfeit. (Go through YouTubes to see what I mean)
They have huge contracts in Afghanistan and Africa to establish network infrastructure and their not going to lose any cash flow anytime soon. Anyhow unlike the US Gov't, Chinese Gov't always subsidize their companies hence why their electronics are cheap and the company will never go out of business.  I know from the outside the company seems to be in trouble but they're not.  A little setback?  Sure not enough to lose a huge market share.  Your point is valid if it was a Non-Chinese company like Apple.  Apple would go out of business without a bailout from the US Gov't.  This is a Chinese company with backing from the Chinese Gov't if they're saying they are surviving make no mistake they're doing better than surviving.

text: @Michael Smith ¬†Michael Smith¬† ¬†Michael Smith¬† I personally have been with oneplus since the oneplus two,  what is concerning with this whole thing is if its been done to here it can be done again and I'm more focused on the idea when the companies are targeted like this it has a ripple effect on everything else in the market today its Huawei tomorrow its someone who won't bounce back.  Its just that we are finally seeing some positive trends with mid tier phones being able to match some features of the flagship devices at an affordable price and to have a setback to that change would overall hurt the consumer's choices when it comes down to price over function.  Not saying there is one in phone manufacturers but a monopoly only benefits itself.  I know we have more than a few choices right now but the main ones are set the market trends. Its how we got the screen ratio wars which led to various setbacks in my opinion.  I personally don't use the headphone jack but it upset a lot of people who use it regularly when it went. Phones are now made thinner less robust more susceptible to breaking in order to fit a trend. Its because of a lack of new ideas that we have these trends that are marketed as what we should buy. We could be further along with battery life than we are if trends weren't the focus. Its down to the major companies being forced to come up with useful concepts rather than just trying to make minor changes seem bigger.  We need new ideas. Samsung was on the right track although I don't think folding phones are the future, they still took a risk with the idea. Without competition the big companies will never have a reason to take risks and we'll pretty much stall out. Apple is already showing some signs of this with their overall sales not matching previous years.  Its inevitable that if there's no push to innovate the rest will follow suit. I'm OK with the phone I currently have now,  no complaints but I'm not sure where things will be when it comes time to upgrade again. I didn't think Huawei would go out of business but I do think the setback with the American market for now at least and this whole subject  is going to see some  changes in how things work going forward. Huawei is just an example of what could happen to other companies that may not be as fortunate.  But I agree that as a company they will be alright its just going to change how they deal with the American market and how they may be viewed depending on how long this lasts and how many people will remember.

text: @Bruce Goldsmith, I agree with your point. The phone market needs to improve with innovation. The technology to do a drastic improvement isn't here yet. At some point we'll reach out zenith in technology and stagnate for a few years until break through comes thru. Huwawei will be an example of companies they'll go after.  US Gov't doesn't go after companies just because.  They go after a particular company such as Huawei or ZTC because they have PLA backing, got caught performing intelligence gathering or violated sanctions and of course they're trying to access our network infrastructure.  Like all major powers, our network carrier are the backup for our military communications.  If US ever go to war and lose all their comms from EMP or other method of destruction the carrier comms will belong to the military for use.  No more civilian use except for maybe ham radio or certain area that the military isn't located. You mentioned OnePlus.  OnePlus is one of those companies US Gov't may not go after because they sell phones only and nothing else.  So the chance that PLA will do anything with OnePlus are slim.  Remember, OnePlus is a Chinese company and they have to follow the Chinese National Intelligence Law - Article 7.  If the Chinese Gov't ask for data of you from OnePlus, OnePlus will provide all data of you to them.  Something to think about. As China get hammered with sanction over and over they are slowly becoming self reliant.  Hence, why they took the Spratly Islands for the large gas and oil deposit.  China knows they have no claim to the islands but they also know no one will challenge them militarily so they'll take it for themselves. Food for thought

Europe wants to maintain a balance with China, the United States and Russia. Simply put, Europe wants a multi-polar world. China is a multi-polar world. It has common interests with Europe. text:
Huawei has a permanent license for the ARM V8 architecture, which is the latest commercial architecture. Huawei can design processors entirely on its own, free from external constraints.


Even if Huawei no longer authorizes a new version of Huawei, it can continue to develop on its own on the basis of previous versions.


Other EDA chip design tools are the same. Huawei can continue to use them even if it can't continue to get new versions. This leaves time for Huawei. In fact, Huawei has other ways to avoid it, such as outsourcing.




Just like you buy a car and you can rebuild the system by yourself, but after-sales is not the follow-up guarantee. This is also the time and space for Huawei to develop itself after the sale.


As for Huawei system, even if Huawei does not make its own system, Google will launch Fuchsia OS. Even Samsung actually prepared its own system many years ago, but it was suspended after Google warned. You can see that Samsung's watch is using its own system, so you can see that as factories are expanding their ecosystem {car, mobile phone, computer, etc.). I'm all preparing my backup plan and I don't want to be controlled by Google all the time. I'm glad to see the birth of the ecosystem outside of iOS and Google.

Huawei should be as ready as Apple to open its own developer conference. This autumn's conference is the highlight.


At the same time, software and architecture authorization belong to service-oriented products. One is that there is no problem of large-scale supply, and I can continue to use them without continuing to supply them, and I have time to continue to improve them. The other is that there is no legal problem, which is also crucial. This means that Huawei's mobile phones and other products can continue to be sold smoothly in all countries of the world without being prohibited by local laws. Except for the United States, of course, they have banned Huawei's products for a long time.

text:
President Trump see how good Huawei/DJI/Hikvision is at 5G/drones/security monitoring, so he Introduce these bans to limit them.
But if they just survive facing those huge troubles, that is the real biggest trouble for US company.
Chinese people would not let Huawei die in this tech war. Maybe it will be suffering in next 10 years, but when the world‚Äôs second largest economy is fully committed to technological self-reliance, it will hurt US company much more than the damage what Chinese companies now receive.
I really love US tech companies such as Google Microsoft AMD and so on. As a tech fan, I really respect the great contributions of these American technology companies to human development. But when Huawei made a very advanced 5G chip, this is also the contribution of Chinese companies to scientific and technological progress. Balong 5000 is no doubt stronger than x50. Qualcomm wants to use the X55 chip to compete with it but still in the lab. Theoretical data is close but still below balong 5000. Don't you think about why Huawei can do this?
The United States completely blocks its exports to China in the military field, finally China began to build its own fighter aircraft. The United States does not allow Chinese astronauts to enter the International Space Station, so they built their own space station. It is because the United States does not allow China to import these things, and China has made these things by itself.
For this technology war, China is suffering in short time. But for the United States, it loses more.
The US government has been telling the world whose product is good. Trump has advertised these companies for free, which will be  the next?

text:
Sure huawei marketing might go in vain after the incident, but there are also other consequences.
1. China, or at least huawei, will be forced to start creating the entire manufacture and biosystem for phones and other products that rely on US products. And for all those products, companies will be losing sales.
2. Companies that wish to do business with the US will now have to evaluate the risk of relentless government interference.
3. The world economy is so chained together, huawei purchases semi-conductors with a worth of over $20 billion annually. The US will also experience a tremendous impact after the tariffs and huawei ban. Companies need to find new business partners to purchase their products in a rather short amount of time.

text: Here's my say: I've been living in china for ten months, after losing the phone that I was using in Europe I bought a Huawei phone: the problem was Huawei phone or other phones for the Chinese market has no google, no Instagram and no facebook instead they have a set of super apps like wechat, Taobao, Meituan that delivers any services you can imagine of. That being said, these apps only work in China, I still have my Chinese version Huawei phone but it's unusable in Europe, so I only use it when I'm traveling in China.  Why am I saying that? My phone today is what other Huawei phones in the future are going to be like: An open source Android, a Huawei store instead of the play store and probably none of the social media you are using because they will probably won't be allowed on the Huawei store. So Huawei is right, they already have a substantial solution to google, I just don't know are they are going to sell it to the market outside of China, but who knows Huawei is a hard working company let's wait and see.

text: Lou you can't bring up articles from South China Morning Post as proof of innocence.  All you have to know is that Huawei is run by the Chinese government. A government that spies on its citizens all the time and assigns them good boy points for toeing the party line.  It's one thing to buy oil from an authoritarian government, it's another thing to let a foreign authoritarian government have access to your country's communication system. That should at least be a red flag to you. Also add to that the fact that Huawei was able to develop so fast in no small part due to forced technology transfers that they obtain from every foreign company that wants to do business in China. Having more options is always nice for consumers, but that doesn't mean that the government should compromise its national security just to have one extra player in the tech market. I guess it all depends on your perspective, if you are more nihilistic and don't care who has your information then I suppose you might not agree with this.

text: Overseas media comments: cracking down on Huawei to tear off the US "Enterprise Freedom" fig leaf 2019 / 05 / 22 the overseas media reported on May 22 that on the 20th, Internet giant Google has shown the extent to which American companies are obedient to White House political opinions. The Commerce Department's decision to put Huawei and its 68 affiliates on the so-called blacklist has wiped out the corporate freedom that the United States is proud of in practice. According to the Russian newspaper's website on May 21, Trump declared a state of emergency on the grounds that his information and communication system was suspected to be threatened, and his order was not yet dry, and US companies doing business with China responded hastily. Google announced that it will no longer provide some services to Huawei, which will not be able to get Android updates. It is a self-evident question of why IT, which at least ostensibly has nothing to do with the country, has suspended its long-term obligations to Huawei in order to comply with Washington's political orders. It is reported that several other US companies have followed Google's lead. Trump declared a state of emergency in the United States, allowing the government to ban domestic communications companies from buying products from foreign companies that "threaten national security," the report said. The move, first aimed at Huawei, shows once again what the White House intends to do to make the United States strong again. Mr Trump said "special threats to US national security, diplomacy and the economy" had emerged, an interpretation designed to prove the need for a state of emergency had nothing to do with reality. The typical discrimination against Huawei shows once again that the US government is doing everything it can around the world to prevent its own companies from facing competition. Russia has been treated similarly in Europe. To sell liquefied natural gas, Americans used the second line of the north stream gas pipeline to scare the old world. Washington is also asking the European Union to give up its own production of weapons for the sake of American manufacturers. According to the report, the willingness of US companies to implement White House political orders makes the agreements they have signed have no legal significance. For the White House, if the United States cannot win, there will be no "fair competition." According to an article published on the website of Hong Kong's Toutiao Daily on May 21, people used to think it was open, but it was not true. Without emergency, US President Trump signed an executive order on 15 May alleging that foreign "hostile forces" pose a national security threat to the communications system of the United States on the grounds that "the country is in a state of emergency." In fact, American companies are prohibited from doing business with Huawei in China, and they are not allowed to buy Huawei's products or sell goods or services to Huawei. Google immediately announced that it would stop some of its business with Huawei phones, the article said. When smartphones started in 2007, Apple developed its own mobile operating system, while Google developed Android, but because Google was unsuccessful in making its own phones, it opened Android to other smartphone makers. To compete with Apple's system. Google has made money from its Android app store and has developed a lucrative business. The article said that when everyone believed that Android was an open system, suddenly in a false state of emergency declared by the President of the United States, the United States could instruct Google to exclude a handset maker from Android. The so-called Libreville field (an economic theory that emphasizes market self-equilibrium and opposes government intervention) turns out to be false, as is the so-called open software system. Under the premise of Trump's "America first" and in the interests of the United States, the United States can forbid others from using what was originally open, deny free trade, and stifle business competition, even for unjustifiable reasons. The article said that this is not only, the United States more prohibited Intel, Qualcomm, Botong and other chip manufacturers to supply parts to Huawei. Similarly, with the US president's "national security", these companies can no longer supply Huawei with the aim of curbing the business and development of Huawei's mobile phones and 5G devices. The article points out that when the United States can use administrative means so directly to crack down on commercial competitors, the idea of Libreville and free trade, which the United States has always advocated, has become a big joke. It turns out that these principles will only be used when they are beneficial to the United States.

author: enduril122

text:
To clarify the issue.
1. There is a lack of clarity about Huawei's financial structures ie we don't know who actually owns Huawei. 
2. Huawei had taken money from the People‚Äôs Liberation Army, China‚Äôs National Security Commission and a third branch of the Chinese state intelligence network.¬†
3. Huawei received an $8.5 million loan from a state-owned bank, something Huawei denies.
4. The World Bank notes that Chinese Development Bank loaned Huawei $10 billion for overseas expansion in 2004.
5. ¬†The Chinese government used Huawei‚Äôs staff to get access codes to infiltrate an unidentified foreign network.

It should be noted that the accusations go back years: long before the election of US President Trump and the increasingly aggressive trade war.(To all who thinks Trump is the one who started this issue.)
The other aspect of spying allegations to bear in mind is 'potential.' Much of what is said about Huawei is not about whether it spies for China or not, but rather focuses on what it 'could' do. Just like how the NSA planted backdoors in Cisco's products for years, the PLA could theoretically do the same with Huawei, it is argued.

"But that‚Äôs just what U.S. investigators found: The chips had been inserted during the manufacturing process, two officials say, by operatives from a unit of the People‚Äôs Liberation Army. text: Most of you just don't know the history and background of Huawei. Huawei is basically a state owned company. Its rise to dominance is because so they could get financial and political backing from the Chinese government, they undercut everyone when the deal was not even profitable for themselves (Nokia bid 2 billion for a project that I knew while Huawei bid 50 million), not to mention they outright stole IP. I was selling technologies in the 90s in China. Huawei stole Cisco source code and had to settle out of court. Their stealing is still alive and kicking today. Just Google it (recently they stole TMobile's testing robot tech, sent a piece of a new screen material back to China to reverse engineer, etc). They encourage and reward employees to steal. The US today looks bad fixing something the West should have fixed a long time ago. Sure the West had enjoyed the cheap tech they otherwise couldn't afford. Huawei ain't innocent. Look at what China has done, banning Google, Facebook, Dropbox, etc. Why is Huawei allowed free access to the West while the West is not allowed in China.  I have no sympathy for Huawei. author: Colin Larson

text:
Huawei has a permanent license for the ARM V8 architecture, which is the latest commercial architecture. Huawei can design processors entirely on its own, free from external constraints.


Even if Huawei no longer authorizes a new version of Huawei, it can continue to develop on its own on the basis of previous versions.


Other EDA chip design tools are the same. Huawei can continue to use them even if it can't continue to get new versions. This leaves time for Huawei. In fact, Huawei has other ways to avoid it, such as outsourcing.




Just like you buy a car and you can rebuild the system by yourself, but after-sales is not the follow-up guarantee. This is also the time and space for Huawei to develop itself after the sale.


As for Huawei system, even if Huawei does not make its own system, Google will launch Fuchsia OS. Even Samsung actually prepared its own system many years ago, but it was suspended after Google warned. You can see that Samsung's watch is using its own system, so you can see that as factories are expanding their ecosystem {car, mobile phone, computer, etc.). I'm all preparing my backup plan and I don't want to be controlled by Google all the time. I'm glad to see the birth of the ecosystem outside of iOS and Google.

Huawei should be as ready as Apple to open its own developer conference. This autumn's conference is the highlight.


At the same time, software and architecture authorization belong to service-oriented products. One is that there is no problem of large-scale supply, and I can continue to use them without continuing to supply them, and I have time to continue to improve them. The other is that there is no legal problem, which is also crucial. This means that Huawei's mobile phones and other products can continue to be sold smoothly in all countries of the world without being prohibited by local laws. Except for the United States, of course, they have banned Huawei's products for a long time.

text:
I have never seen such disinformation in a long time. 
#1 US have not used Huawei networking equipment in over 10 years. Last company was Clearwire which converted all that equipment to Samsung before Sprint took control of company. 
#2 they have plenty of 5g equipment that are not just Ericsson. Another being Samsung and Alcatel/Nokia. 
#3 you would have to be a complete idiot to have bought a Huawei phone if you live in the US because they lack the frequency support for all US carriers. 
Huawei has continued to steal intellectual property and most of their tech is stolen from some bizarre contracts with manufacturers looking for deals for a Chinese manufacturer to produce products for next to nothing.
author: Dave Oneill

text: Don't get too twisted into a pretzel. Worst case scenario, if China does not respect intellectual property rights and free market, what it means is a decoupling of the Chinese economy from the US economy and possibly the western world. China is no longer a developing country where it needs special considerations for tariffs and other accommodations. With all the pundits talking of it surpassing the US GDP and challenging US security, the West needs to quickly level the playing field or it will find itself looted and insignificant.

text: This hurts America tech firms the worst, those within the supply chain. Software isn‚Äôt an issue, just brought a chinese version of Mate 20 X and it doesn‚Äôt have Google services, till I‚Äôll be installing them - so no real change there. But Huawei, Samsung, and other firms aren‚Äôt looking for an excuse to tool up - these company‚Äôs have contingency plans, both been developing chips and OS for years looking for a point to jump ship. text:
The word you were looking for was Propaganda Lew üòÇ 

There are options to root devices and side load apps (depending on how far this will go). But what bothers me the most is that we tend to overlook how restrictive China is in allowing American companies to sell their goods to the people of China. Software companies like FB and Twitter, Google (YouTube etc) and all of the rest aren't even allowed to be used on their devices. But that doesn't even account for the stolen (or I guess the PC version would be "copied" versions) they use instead. Hardware and other products are just as bad (now it might have become less restricted recently and I am a bit off here but you get my meaning). 

This is a horrible thing to do, and I hope it is resolved. But saying it's an attack on their People is a bit much. Especially when you compare it to what their government allows them to do with IP and what it when does to them. It's really an attack on the company's dealings outside of China.

Android compatibility, the fastest autumn¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† I have science and technology fantasy¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 05-2123:10¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Huawei self-research operating system "Hongmeng" confirmation! Android compatibility, the fastest autumn¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Recently, the U.S. Department of Commerce listed Huawei as a "list of entities", announcing that American enterprises are prohibited from selling high-tech products to Huawei, which directly pushes Huawei "to Liangshan". After the incident, Hu Tingbo, president of Huawei Hess, wrote overnight that "Huawei spare tire chips have all been corrected", meaning that Hessi Kirin will become Huawei's main chip supplier and get rid of its dependence on American semiconductors. Soon afterwards, people became worried about switching from semiconductors to operating systems, because Google claimed that it had stopped doing some business with Huawei, and Huawei would not be able to use some of its applications in the future. What if Android didn't use them?¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† What if you really don't use Android? In fact, the author has done such an analysis before. Huawei is the third largest smartphone manufacturer in the world, and will soon become the second largest. If Huawei cannot use Android, is it not forced to "self-supporting portal" Huawei? It's not hard for Huawei to build an operating system in its current strength, but this kind of payment has really happened, and it's hard to say that it won't need Android in the future. Huawei has to keep its hands on it.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Huawei has the capital to get rid of Android's self-supporting portal. In March, Huawei's consumer CEO Yu Chengdong said that "if Huawei had to abandon Windows and Android systems and turn to internal solutions", as long as Yu Chengdong said that it was very sure, including recently Yu Chengdong also said in his circle of friends that "Huawei not only has the ability to do core work." It seems that Huawei's internal "secret weapon" is not only chips, but also systems.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† According to the information on the Internet, Yu Chengdong recently revealed in the group of old friends formed by famous Internet personality Fang Xingdong that as soon as this autumn and as late as next spring, Huawei's OS will probably be on the market. At the same time, Huawei's OS has opened up mobile phones, computers, tablets, televisions, cars, smart wear, and unified into an operating system. That is to say, Huawei has played a big chess game in the system, which has directly opened up many fields. More noteworthy is that Huawei's system will be compatible with Android software.

author: An Smith

text: Indeed it does feel unprecedented and very negative. As a European I want to see hard evidence and proof of claims such as made by the US about Huawei. Without hard proof it is like an economic act of war and the international community should probably sanction the US  for it rather than blindly follow. Given that the US is run now by the most obviously lying, self-serving and hypocritical conman ever to be president, my suspicion is that US companies are likely doing as much spying as they claim Huawei is doing, if not more. And even if the companies themselves are not (actively) spying (more so than they are kind of open about, their business model still is to sell access to and information about their users after all), all of the world's data in the cloud is now up for grabs by US authorities under the Cloud Act. It is quite sad to see this shift from international collaboration and trust to nationalistic head bashing.  But it does point out an inconvenient truth and as such may ultimately cause improvement. There need to be more options in the OS space and our entire digital lives probably should not be entrusted to a handful of companies all headquartered in the US.

The EU is literally getting their members bought up by China (particularly, the poorer countries), to the point that China has already made those countries veto any proposal that is against their national interests in the EU. This has been happening in the last 5 years so it is already far too late for the EU to avoid picking a side when they are interfering in your politics. Italy joining in the Belt and Road plan only reassures this.

It's an even worse situation for the UK which already know that Huawei is a threat but have dug themselves into a hole due to their short sighted policies as their recent report states at the end of 2018.

Edit: As for European companies, they are getting scooped up by Chinese firms that are given money by the Communist Party of China with many examples (not just in technology). The EU not supporting the companies that they do have (such as the 5G networks of their allies, like Nokia and Ericsson) and their inability to protect their own companies has already caused a serious issue on their   economy (it will just grow worse in the future).

text:
@Saeglopur89 As far as I know, 5G is offered exclusively by Huawei, if some countries want Huawei, I assume it is likely because other providers don't have 5G yet, not because Huawei's 5G is cheap. It's not cheap. When CDMA, GSM, PHS were competing, China adopted European's GSM, then we see the rise of Nokia, Simonsen, Ericsson, many other European giants and the fall of American's Motorola, etc. You probably never even heard of Japanese PHS which was completely killed in the competition. Then US allied with China and won the 3G competition. Europe and China partner agian in 4G race against US and resulted in the dominance of European FD LTE and Chinese TD LTE. Along the way consumers got faster cheaper internet.
Again, The right way to compete is making better products, like we did with 2G, 3G, 4G. Chinese 5G might win this round, so what? We have a long future ahead of us, we shouldn't stop playing at 5G and fight to death.

text:
Well, here come all of the idiots supporting Huawei. 

The funny thing is that even the Chinese propaganda sponsored by the Chinese government like the South China Morning Post, People's Daily, etc.    already made articles talking about Huawei's actions leading to a negative view of the company abroad and that action was bound to happen due to Huawei's actions, along with their inability to ease the security concerns and address the evidence brought by the Western governments and Security agencies. 

If even the Chinese propaganda can admit that, then what does that say of the idiots on here saying that it was due to Huawei being better than the competition (seriously, that's one of the foolish excuses you can make)? 

As for Huawei, they deserve it. I do not think that Huawei will go bankrupt to this because they are obviously under the direct control of the Communist Party of China. I do hope that it makes them lose their market share abroad, encourages other countries to ban their network infrastructure (along with the company) and for them to reconsider their policies.

text:
I think you're missing out on some very important facts.
Yes, im the west we certainly do have a free market and competition. Whenever a tech company in the west releases a product or plans on doing so, it first has to get the money to start advertising it and making it look good from a competive point of view. 

So, conclusively, companies need to save up enough money to plan for products, make them have good quality and producing them.

In China, companies like Huawei are sponsored DIRECTLY by the government of China. That basically means that the reason why they have become so famous and big in western markets is not really just because of good marketing, but because they were financially unlimited. They can do whatever they want from a financial perspective and dont need to focus on basic business aspects. Aspects, which are essentially for Western companies. If they dont have enough money, capacities and ressources to fastly build up 5G infrastructure, they cant accept the offer, whereas Huawei just goes to chinese government, asks for some millions or billions more and is just fine.

Of course, this policy isnt really what I want. But seeing it from the perspective mentioned above I certainly DO understand that US companies are prohibited from dealing with Huawei (and likely much more coming)

If you disagree or have legitimate proof that I'm wrong, comment and share your proof. If not, not just talk bullshit and saying I'm wrong unreasonable. 

Dont @ me

text: If you want proof that Huawei and the Chinese government are colluding, there is no bigger proof than Huawei's sudden technological leap ahead of it's competitors.  This is probably due to China's forced technology transfers of companies that want to do business in the country.  With it's ties to the Chinese government, it would have access to all of these technologies from different companies, giving it an edge over competitors who would only have it's own homegrown technologies to rely on.  It just seems unlikely, that a new competitor would suddenly be able to develop the needed disparate technologies to outstrip other companies that have been developing the same technology for a longer time, unless they had access to breakthroughs from other companies.

text:
There are number of facts support US claims.

1. Huawei breaks US laws
- Iran sanction violation by using a proxy company to sell IT equipments to Iran

2. Huawei steals intellectual properties (IP)
- Theft of Cisco switch codes
- Theft of T-mobile testing equipment
- Theft of Samsung flexible/foldable display tech via 2 Chinese OLED manufacturers

3. Chinese law requires Huawei to assist Chinese intelligence (spy) services.
- This is clearly written in Chinese law

4. Huawei network equipment has many security vulnerabilities
- UK Huawei review board found numerous security vulnerabilities in their equipment

5. Huawei lies a lot and breaks promises
- Huawei lies about stealing Cisco switch codes for their switches (later pays Cisco and promises not to do it)
- Huawei lies about stealing T-mobile equipment saying it was done by an individual employee and not by Huawei yet later investigations revealed Huawei gives bonuses to employees who steal other companies' IP.
- Huawei promises UK review board that it will fix its security vulnerability but even after a decade it still hasn't fixed the problems.  Review board recently concluded Huawei is either unable or unwilling to fix the problems

text:
China has already said it's done negotiating. It's going to wait until our next election before making any further trade negotiations in the hopes that we will have a new president that will negotiate more favorable terms. We have 532 days until we know who the president will be on Jan 20th, 2021 for the following 4 years. I have no doubt China has made preparations to sit and wait through any pain between now and Nov 3, 2020 to get a solid trade deal for a minimum of 4 years one way or the other. The US is really pushing its allies to restrict Huawei in their countries, but given the lack of evidence and rising tensions with the US, the EU is still largely planning to go ahead with Huawei 5G purchases. 

We will just have to wait and see where this goes, but I'm not optimistic on having a resolution until early 2021. China has a massive population and a command economy. They can manipulate their currency and shift production to other industries to weather tariffs and bans for years if need be. No one wins trade wars, but if it escalates and becomes a game of chicken to see who caves first as tariffs on both sides rise sky high, I don't think China will be the one to blink first.

text: Lew, I think this is a politic issue more than something aimed directly towards Huawei. Trump has huawei as a target because it makes a mediatic impact, it makes an economical impact and a political impact. This isa comercial war, a new kind of a cold war between china and USA. This tells us China will move their pieces and cut as many supplies as possible to the US and their companies. And that will hit both ways, but it eill hit harder in the american economy. It goes way beyond 5g and smartphones or tech... If Trump is willing to sacrifice that much of the sales income of US companies, China Is willing to face a crisis with some employments and sacrifice people and companies in order to protect their own brands, their political power and their greatest chinesse company that has become such a reference not only in chinesse soil, but worldwide. They are like the chinesse flagship company in the world. I mean, thid can actually turn things into a very dangerous direction where we have to take into consideration one thing: it has been about 5 years of WW3 chit chat, and this move from the US can make China do something to escalate things and that can get us in a very dangerous territory considering all the dues and interests between both countries. text:
Yeah, Lou, it's a sticky pudding to be sure, and you're not really getting the full scoop either. 
Here's the thing, this ban is bullshit and it should be called out right out of the starting blocks  
We are, many of us, living in the Huawei 'ecosystem' as you enjoy calling it. We use their handsets and our carriers use their radio gear, and are set to develop into the next generation, the 5g network. 
What is the basis for banning all sprawling  infrastructure?
None. No basis whatsoever. You can't accuse and then act based on the complaint. You need evidence to have a case. The onus is on each of us to do the diligence for ourselves. I appreciated you've had a hard time trying to prove a negative as it were. 
But the fact is that no evidence exists beyond a declaration of affiliation to a country. When Apple disavow themselves from any government then you might have a point. Until that day, let's just not get tied into this hysterical ban which they have already rooled back on and which is not practical in any case. 
The USA may declare war on the world, but they may find themselves ignored if the world is busy moving on with tech.

text: Cisco and other US brands are notorious for including hidden admin accounts with user/pw built into firmware for "servicing" or "included on accident." The US Govt is known to intercept electronics to modify them with spyware and hardware backdoors. Huawei is just a pressure point for trade negotiations with China. Huawei has done everything they can to assure everyone their systems aren't compromised. They've allowed inspections, offered assurances, etc. If anything were found, they'd lose ALL their business, so it profits them nothing to include backdoors, and so far nothing has been found. Some say the very nature of 5G technology would allow Huawei to inject malware at a later date undetected, but if that's true, then so could any provider. I wouldn't put it past China to try to leverage their tech to spy on other governments, but I also know that Huawei is under a microscope and once their reputation is tarnished for spying, they won't get a 2nd chance in the marketplace which will drop them immediately.  What's more important to China? Profiting from a multi-billion dollar industry or listening in on some foreign intel for a short time? I'm going to bet on the multi-billion dollar industry as being most important to their future.

text:
Couple points: Huawei's main business is not smartphones. That didn't start until 2003. Their main business has always been telecom infrastructure like 4G, 5G. Google is not going to affect that. The founder of Huawei is right when he says that 5G will still continue. (Though Trump's gang will be plotting ways to stop that).

Smartphones sales will be hit by the google ban. But the Chinese will overcome that (much to the regret of google). Remember when the US banned the Chinese from the International Space Station some years ago? That didn't stop the Chinese. Their space station is expected to start next year. The ISS is expected to stop by 2024.

And through Android and a browser one can still access gmail, youtube etc. with a new Huawei phone as Lew says...

Also Huawei has business dealings with telecom companies world over and they might be affected. So what's the reason for Trump's insanity? Just plain pettiness that he can't intimidate China. And obviously he doesn't care about you...!

text:
There are number of facts support US claims.

1. Huawei breaks US laws
- Iran sanction violation by using a proxy company to sell IT equipments to Iran

2. Huawei steals intellectual properties (IP)
- Theft of Cisco switch codes
- Theft of T-mobile testing equipment
- Theft of Samsung flexible/foldable display tech via 2 Chinese OLED manufacturers

3. Chinese law requires Huawei to assist Chinese intelligence (spy) services.
- This is clearly written in Chinese law

4. Huawei network equipment has many security vulnerabilities
- UK Huawei review board found numerous security vulnerabilities in their equipment

5. Huawei lies a lot and breaks promises
- Huawei lies about stealing Cisco switch codes for their switches (later pays Cisco and promises not to do it)
- Huawei lies about stealing T-mobile equipment saying it was done by an individual employee and not by Huawei yet later investigations revealed Huawei gives bonuses to employees who steal other companies' IP.
- Huawei promises UK review board that it will fix its security vulnerability but even after a decade it still hasn't fixed the problems.  Review board recently concluded Huawei is either unable or unwilling to fix the problems

author: G Mason

text:
Argument makes no sense... Despite the obvious grammatical errors, which I'll just overlook (despite your name) and assume it was just a rushed edit, and say that you need to think about the effect this has beyond the handful of Google Apps. *Enthusiast's answer would be to just root and side load those apps. But that means that other apps, which won't work if you're rooted, are gone now (while you can trick some apps into believing you're not rooted when you are it's all a hassle). All of that said - you'd still have to be an enthusiast, because the majority of the market would never go through all of that. *You'd also have to trick Google into believing you're device isn't what it is, if they decide to be dicks.

But what's really at the core of this are things that we can't even know yet. We actually won't know the full implications until they release a new device (hopefully it'll never come to that). Once they've lost all of their peripherals etc. It's like saying you'd buy an iPhone, even if it had a horrible screen, slow processor, inability to connect with the radio bands needed for your ISP, slow RAM etc etc etc. This is just as much about the hardware, as it is about software. Top that off with some wonky operating system etc. (We currently get mad about skinned OS's, but somehow a completely new one will be great and the marketplace (store) will be good too?) Nope this needs to end or it's unlikely anyone will buy one.

author: Anon M

text:
If Huawei rolls out a new OS, now it's probably a great time. I know Android may already have 1 million apps out there, but I mean come on, how many apps do you really have on your phone? I believe the apps we are using on a daily basis are mostly within the top 500 list. Plus, nowadays, a lot of apps are built with hybrid techs (PhoneGap, React Native, etc) so, it would not be so hard for app dev companies to make a new variant. Google could burn itself with this move.

UPDATE: Just saw a press release from Huawei, their own OS (also open source) will be available this fall, it will compatible with all existing Android apps, so no redevelopment needed. 

I see some people in the replies say a new OS won't be succeeded since the MS Windows Phone failed years ago. So I need to point out that Windows Phone's failure is a result of 3 major reasons:
1) Significantly different user experience (also inferior) than iOS/Android. 
2) Lacks big manufacturer support 
3) Compatibility issue.

Those 3 problems won't exist in Huawei's case.
1) The user experience will remain the same as their existing modified-android OS.
2) Huawei is a major player itself and highly likely we will see support from MI, OnePlus, Meizu, etc. Well, basically, all big players except Samsung and Apple.
3) Compatible with all existing Android apps. If Google doesn't allow Huawei to bundle with their apps (Gmail, Maps), just install them separately with the APK files. Maybe it will cost your extra 10 minutes.

What doesn't kill you makes you stronger.

"NPR's¬†Planet Money¬†has learned that more than 13,500 immigrants, mostly Chinese, who were granted asylum status years ago by the U.S. government, are facing possible deportation.

As the Trump administration turns away asylum-seekers at the border under more restrictive guidance issued by Attorney General Jeff Sessions, U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, Immigration and Customs Enforcement and the Executive Office for Immigration Review are considering stripping asylum status from immigrants who won it years ago.

Immigration officials are moving against these immigrants in a sweeping review that federal authorities say is related to a 2012 investigation into asylum mills. During that probe, federal prosecutors in New York rounded up 30 immigration lawyers, paralegals and interpreters who had helped immigrants fraudulently obtain asylum in Manhattan's Chinatown and in Flushing, Queens. The case was dubbed Operation Fiction Writer."

text: This wont hurt Huawei as much as we may think. Least we forget there are Asian equivalents to the tools/apps,  but as mention in the West it will surely devastate their sales.  Huawei is a major player . And 'as mentioned' if China retaliates by banning Apple.  Forget it.. Apple sales world wide will plummet. because All of apples components that are sourced from China will have to be manufactured someplace else. Places with equally skilled employment but also having higher cost labor, (India). The price of Apple products will skyrocket.  killing the company. A trade war with CHina hurts the US far more than it does hurt CHina,  because China today is not China decades ago. They whole interest in providing cheap labor to the US was for growth in technology. We gave it to them by closing our own domestic manufacturing in favor of cheap chinese labor.  same thing with India.  But now they have the know how to manufacture and create products. They know the tools and software, even if they may have to replicate as such.  they have the ability to do so.    essentially whats going to happen.. Trumps trade war will backfire on the US.

text:
Specifically because Huawei refused to cooperate with the NSA and allow them to compromise the security on their hardware. This is why Huawei is being targeted while other Chinese companies are not. text:
You're right about the fate of Huawei Lew. And you're definitely right about the double-edged sword that Trump swings would hurt both sides. However, your hesitation about the political struggle between these two nations just reflects what US government's complicated conclusion about China - You don't know if you should eliminate this "honest" potential friend, or defend this "threat" before it's too late. The fact is, China is always an option of both. They want all the other countries to become its dependence, to accept its ridiculous totalism ideology. They could be a friend to the ones who follow this totalism ideology or a threat to the ones who didn't agree.


This duality of China's global strategy made it a very difficult rival, it is both your enemy and friend at the same time. But always remember its goal had never changed - to become the only leader of the world following its own ideology. The things you mentioned, the achievement China had reached, were mostly built on its totalism ideology. Foxcon workers had suffered a lot to produce cheap and stable iPhone for the world, and Huawei workers as well. You can even found suicidal news from both of these two companies even on the Chinese newspaper in the past decades very often. If this is the cost of the global trade goal and international influence, was it worth for?


So I hereby conclude as you mentioned: This is a war. But it's not only about one company, or one industry. This is a political war between US "good" democracy and CCP totalism. You probably don't have to choose a side now, but will be soon.

text: We have seen the same thing play out a few decades ago. .China is being put into a trade war with the US just like Japan in the 80s and 90s. During the 80s, Japan was on its way to overtake US until Washington responded by putting 100% tariffs on electronics, force voluntary restrictions on the aggressor's auto, steel, and machine industries, and adopt laws that restricted the country's steel, lumber, and sugar industries. The United States finally achieved a tactical victory in the war with the 1985 Plaza Accord when the U.S. argued that it and Japan should abandon the fixed exchange rates that had prevailed after the Second World War. The result was that U.S. imports dropped in price as the dollar fell and Japan entered the bubble economy, which would lead to the Lost Decade. Japan' economy never recovered from this. Chinese leaders have promised themselves that they won't repeat Japan's mistake. Whether it be China or the next superpower, US would do anything or find excuses to curb the next upcoming superpower.

text: Recall that LTE stands for Long Term Evolution -- it was designed to be around for a long time. However, with the quick transition we had with 2G, 3G then 4G, investors and marketers pressured the industry for the next big thing. To answer, we implemented VoLT (Voice over LTE) and WiFi calling, but this wasn't enough. Then came 5G. However, 5G from a technical perspective is not feasible in the US due to the average free-space path distances and LoS limitations at the frequencies initially proposed. This is why US companies are not invested in building out 5G-it simply won't reliably work here, engineers know this. China can likely deploy it due to the population density there, but here it simply won't work except for perhaps convention centers and other high traffic locations. Also do not be fooled by AT&T's 5G network -- since the terms '2G, 3G, 4G and 5G' are not regulated, AT&T simply renamed their 4G network by calling it '5G.'

text:
Proprietary tech is freedom to it‚Äôs creators.
To others it‚Äôs fear.

As a monopoly Apple has ruled with an iron fist for years with its proprietary hardware/software combos. But alas it‚Äôs fortress has been penetrated. I once told a lady in an Apple store about the parts in here iMac she was so proud of...she lost her gourd. (Intel chips, foreign ram, alternate brand HDD) So I asked ‚ÄòWhat makes this an Apple product? That glowing little logo?‚Äô...üò∂

But that‚Äôs exactly what others such as the Nazis did, they were years beyond in military advances so the U.S. ‚Äòborrowed‚Äô their scientists to catch up. Same thing happened with Russia.

You can seemingly cut off a nation and it‚Äôs supply (e.g. North Korea) but it will find a way to continue on, however when it does survive the kitten has now grown into a mighty independent lion and the powers are reversed.

I think that‚Äôs covered in ‚ÄòDictatorship & War 101‚Äô

Google Service is just a bunch of apps. If a manufacture don't have the license, they cannot ship their phone with those apps. But they can put Google services in their app store. 
If you buy a xiaomi phone in China, it doesn't comes with Google service. If you tell the staff you want to use it outside of China, the staff will just install the google service package from their own mi app store. 
Same thing can be done in Huawei phone. They can make the process of installing GApps as easy as possible in OS level.
author: Tsz Fung Li

text: Don't really understand all that fuss about Google: with each and every of my android smartphones, tablets or tv boxes, first thing I did was to deactivate (and if I could, but generally couldn't except by rooting the device) all the patented Google apps: Chrome, Gmail, Drive, Google search, Google Maps, Google PlayStore. There are other much better web browsers, mail clients, search engines, cloud storage or Maps apps outside of Google world. The only one I use on a regular basis is YouTube but I can (and I do) download on other stores than the PlayStore - and I update it only when I want it (saving time on the daily updates you have with playstore, plus the pain in the neck of bugged updates and the almost impossible task of downgrading in case of incompatibility, while "parallel" stores leave the choice of the version you want or need to install... As for the 5G issue, let's say that 90% of the world doesn't really need it: the essential is to get rid of dead zones and have a decent connection: even a 2G one remains wishful thinking in some parts (even in "developed" countries like UK or continental Europe...

text:
It‚Äôs pretty obvious there isn‚Äôt a back door, however it‚Äôs also pretty obvious that China are at the stage where they want to create market dominance and make brand names. There is a law that all Chinese companies must cooperate with the spie  services if the government asks. Unlike in America, there is no possibility of a company challenging a government organisation like FBI vs Apple. Or of protests of google employees against cooperation with us military.

China has extensive human rights abuse that dwarves anything America might do. The re-education camps of millions of innocent Muslims for example. The arrest of anyone who disagrees with the party. There is also decades of theft of America and European  IP. That‚Äôs why these Chinese companies are now so good. They stole, and then bought western tech companies. And the West got greedy, and let them do it.

The action now is a precaution against a future dominant China that will abuse its position. They have no difficulty abusing individual human rights and privacy for both Chinese and foreigners now. Just look at the absurd social points system they have. How they monitor any negative information. How much worse will they be with more power. They will make America look like angels with their attacks on your rights if they get power.

I don‚Äôt think they are doing back doors,but the signs are there that America would be stupid to let them f
Gain dominance in the market with their close ties to a truly evil Chinese government. (Not the Chinese people) 

I do t like trump, and he should have got support from his allies,  but the west has to face China now before it‚Äôs too late for all of us.

text:
Trump is attacking the Huawei's supply chain hoping to cripple Huawei.
China could also join this game by reducing or even cease delivery of rare earth metal to any company that comply with the Trump ban. No rare earth metal = no high-tech components = no high-tech products.
Trade deficit, trade war, Huawei ban all comes to one point US doesn't want to be the second best. Not in economy, technology, military power, etc. If Huawei ban fails they will come up with something else. The Trump election slogan: "Make America great again" says it all. They want to revive the glory days of the past by reviving old industries (mining coal, steel and aluminum manufacturing) instead of investing in the future thing that could prolong their leader position. But it is obvious that they do something wrong: heavily investing on military in peace time, slashing health care, neglecting the infrastructure, deinvesting on future talent with their immigration restrictions, abusing their allies.

text:
Before everyone jumps on Trump it was Obama in 2012 that determined Huawei to be a threat to U.S. national security. It was Huawei that lied to the U.S. about their relationship with Iran and North Korea (circumventing sanctions).

Competition and the "Trade War" takes a backseat to national security interests. 

Unfortunately I feel like this video is a little off target painting the issue as elimination of competition and winning the trade war. This is not about the marketplace or free markets.

I do agree with Lew on one point though. This is only scary because we have all of our eggs in one of only a few baskets (Apple, Google, Amazon, Samsung, and Huawei). Time to start supporting the "little guy" a little more.

text:
The devil is in the details, there's a reason why the US is doing this to China. Huawei is very closely tied to the Chinese government and since China is trying to take over as the world's biggest superpower, having a bunch of government controlled Chinese tech all over the world is very useful to them as it's tech that they could use to disrupt communications or to steal sensitive information.

This is not just a tariff, trading, competition or economical issue, it's a National Security issue.

I too hope that the US and China can come to some mutually beneficial agreement and end this, which will very likely happen soon, but Huawei shouldn't be trusted regardless, unless they cut all ties from the Chinese government.

text:
This is going to make life much harder for us Americans living in China. I've been here and I speak Chinese. Having a limited understanding of the culture I can point out that almost all Chinese media and most individuals do not ever refer to themselves in the singular. Its always "We Chinese, us Chinese, the Chinese." If you have offended a mainland Chinese citizen there is a very good chance that they will explain the situation to their friends in words and writing in a way which paints your actions as an offense against all Chinese people. The culture here pushes people to identify as a group and not as individuals.

This will have me answering questions like "Do all Americans hate the Chinese?" or responding to comments telling me to get out of their country for months. This is going to actively affect the lives of American expats in China. So fucking thank you Trump.

text:
This isn't a particular attack on Lew but... 

Can we PLEASE stop saying that any US company can "compete" (manufacturing-wise) with China?
The Chinese treat their worker-force like garbage. This, and among other things, makes their goods cheap or at least a good bang for your buck. US companies aren't blameless as a lot of their manufacturing gets done in China, as well as other parts of southeast Asia.
Should we really want manufacturing in the States (or any western country for that matter) "competing" with borderline slave labor in China? What exactly would that entail? 

Don't even get me started on IP laws and protections...

The American government is ran by thugs. Pompeo and Bolton are running the show, while giving Trump what he wants on the economic blackmail. Here is the deal, US does not want competition when it comes to 5G, Huawei invested billions and about 3-5 years ahead of everyone else. This is not about national security, because mind you NSA, CIA, FBI all spy not only on Americans but everyone in the world, especially "ALLIES" if anyone remembers Merkel being tapped, while hiding it from everyone and blaming other nations for something they do themselves. 
Here is the deal they do not want competition, they do not want fair game. If CIA and NSA are so good at what they do, where is the proof of Huawei spying? Nothing? Surely as in a court of law, everything needs to be backed up by facts. 
Anyone remembers Iraq having WMD? Powel with his little bottle in US showing it as a proof? Lybia? Russian meddling? Where is a single piece of evidence. 

Now thinking rationally, how does Huawei become a bigger threat than Iran or North Korea, ISIS etc? They are not punishing Huawei as a whole, they are punishing smartphone users so they can switch (hopefully to Apple).  Shame on Google that could not find a way, not challenge them in court. Then again considering insane censorship that Google is pushing in their search together with bias that has already been proven.  This does not surprise me. text:
So the US Commerce Department has temporarily lifted the ban until August 19 which proves this ban goes a lot deeper than just Huawei not being able to sell Android phones without gapps. This is tacit admittance that the disruption this will cause for both in the US and with US allies will be pretty big. I have a theory:



With this ban Trump is bluffing and never really planned on going all the way through with the ban, but he's so unpredictable(for better or for worse) that the CCP won't risk not capitulating on some level. Trump also knows that the hardliners of Xi's regime will try to influence him to push back at the U.S and escalate things, even if it hurts them economically(see Iran and N.Korea). An escalation can lead to global economic slow down which will affect the U.S economy and jobs, his approval ratings and his chances of getting reelected so even he will capitulate on some level. G20 summit in Japan is in June and they(Trump and Xi) will likely meet and iron things out... somewhat. Both will make compromises and both will claim victory.

Taking that Huawei and CCP money huh? 
Huawei is state-backed, which means cost is not a factor when it comes to what can be delivered to the customer at an affordable price.
That's not a free and open market, on top of the forced technology transfers & heavy restrictions placed on foreign companies operating in China. 
The reason behind the 5G situation is more so about controlling the type of world we will live in; continue open and free communication, or heavy government censorship (It will literally be a 1984 George Orwell world).

text:
As SW engineer, yes it is complicated to identify if a system have "back door", but there are no magic in engineer, every signal send can record, every packet transmit can be traced, which port is open, what socket is send/recv , what is  inside packet all can be traced and analyzed. Software and hardware  is human product guided by specific rules and law of physics, every product I saw always have bugs, through these bugs, venerability exposed, sometime it is hard to say it is a human error or did it on purpose.  
Communication equipment just like highway , its job is efficiently deliver packets from any source to any destination as quickly as possible, if you don't want others to see you have sex in the car on highway, don't build your car transparent, it is application's job to ensure your data encrypted checksummed , don't send plain text content, anybody can capture the wireless signal and analyze the packet if they are not encrypted. In that sense Huawei's role in information security is overstated. 
I have no doubt this is just extend of America First policy, kill approaching second is one way to ensure first. The spirt of Law , innocent until proven guilty,  The spirt of free and liberty , competition achieve excellency. All doesn't matter in the font of America first. It is not about Communist, human right, western civilization  vs east, white vs color or even right vs wrong, it is America first. 
By the way accuse Huawei CEO is ex-military guy so it must be proxy of government make me think  if I eat at KFC does it make me a better US citizen. d  e
author: Hard Way

text:
Still watching, but I'll try to comment as I go.
The problem with banning Apple from China is something that can't be done because of 3 reasons:
1- Banning Apple in China will force one of the biggest electronic manufacturer on the planet to fire tens of thousands of people, and we are talking of a market where the government promised that will always give jobs to people.
2- Foxconn IS NOT a Chinese manufacturer is a Taiwanese one, Taiwan can easily use their Indian (not sure if they're up and running yet) factories to manufacture iPhones only since they own the technology that makes them already.
3- China is a country based on face, iPhone is a status symbol, having the latest iPhone is the way to really flex on other people. Take that away and the people would not be happy.

I'm an expat living in China, so I can see how and what is going on and, even if I'm not American, I can understand where the trade war and all this problems come from. This measures come after China declined and revised the entire trade agreement, while up in the US they used to have a real free market until some months ago.
Is not easy to comment on this without getting super political, but in all honesty this can go only in 2 ways.
1- fix everything when China finally decides to follow an agreement
2- get your rifle ready, because it will go down pretty pretty fast..

As for competition, I can't speak about NA in general, but in Europe Huawei has been a major player since forever albeit in the high/mid and not the flagship segment. That also can help you understand how Europe is reacting

As for the Government implication, I think that the USA is using the classic "eye for an eye" policy...as for 5G..do we really need it? In Italy (where I'm from) is already a miracle if we get 4G in some areas...

text:
It sucks for Huawei. The US ban will compromise the company's dealings with many of the services provided by other companies based in the United States including Google and the android platform on smartphones set to release later this year. We are to blame for the rise of Chinese manufacturing prowess. Many American companies began manufacturing in China giving incentives to China to partner up for mutual benefit where they supply the cheap labor while building industries. This allowed for Chinese manufacturing to advance at a faster pace especially considering the population. The Chinese government has made sure that they have Chinese people who are working in these factories. 
Here is a harsh truth nobody seems to want to admit: corporate espionage is practiced daily by companies from all different countries and government espionage is a certainty. China has abetted companies who have stolen intellectual property and patents. An example is Microsoft Windows being used without licensing from Microsoft, in China...
Would you have trouble saying I'm not buying crude oil from Putin even though my society is in desperate need of gasoline from Russia if that were the case? My honest opinion is that most people wouldn't support money going to Putin. The double standard applies here only because the  difference is we have a better idea of the inner workings of the Russian government, and are ignorant of the inner workings of the Chinese government. We therefore are left thinking that China is the place where most of "my products" come from that save me money plus there stuff is as good as Japanese stuff used to be... 
This isn't the actual case. Let's look at what the standards for an employee are as an employee in Japan versus China, world's of differences as well as  regulatory practices and laws.
In the end it comes down to this: if Putin was pushing for Russian currency to become the World monetary currency people would rail that he is a corrupt enemy dictator. Tanks running over students during protests... all forgotten, at least now you can leave Russia much more easily than the USSR, leave China and you are considered a Chinese asset abroad by the Chinese government akin to the glorious KGB days of the USSR. I don't trust Huawei, Samsung, Apple, Google... Governments they will use your information and they will spy and companies want opportunities to make more money and will use personal info. You see my family came here from Russia after living under the communist regime. My friends from China are not so endeared to China. China shows the same propensities as the USSR in exertion of its perceived borders. If I wouldn't trust Putin and wouldn't want Russian currency to become the world monetary currency I wouldn't want the alternatively better organized Communist dictatorship to have their currency placed instead of Russia.
I believe communist ideology antithetical to the way our societies wish to function. Communism is yet another anachronism in our society. Canadian companies including BlackBerry have had issues with vulnerabilities from way back. Companies including Huawei and other suppliers of Canadas 4G equipment and antennas have had backdoors found and dealt with behind closed doors by companies buying the products. The telecom Giants, the big 3, have hidden some of the shadier practices behind closed boardroom doors. Huawei had once been in a particular instance in Italy, that recently noted how there was a lengthy dialogue surrounding the backdoors found in their telecommunications equipment and how there were multiple instances of such behavior and how long it took to resolve. The fact is that Huawei was pretty shady and didn't immediately fulfill promises to remove backdoors. If it were leaked that these instances have been repeated when the Huawei tech was under scrutiny in many other countries by telecom companies making purchases for 4G networks, people would be very unhappy. Unfortunately telecommunications companies are trying to make billions and don't want to spend more money to begin their 5G networks, hence they will likely be untruthful and downplay the threat possibilities and deny that they have in some instances found vulnerabilities related to backdoors but resolved the issue in private in a manner they found acceptable. We tend to be a society based on perception rather than truth and the belief that a good PR campaign can cure the perception the public has of a particular thing in any instance. We rely heavily on Chinese products so hopefully our "devil's" ('elected' political leaders)will work out the trade war and we will have a deal.
Huawei being put in the penalty box is ok if you are playing the same game, hopefully it will not be long before resolution is found.

text:
Did you mean Huawei are being made a scapegoat?

Pretty good analysis of this artificially created situation.

I can't help thinking that the situation is more political than anything else. I heard China had bought the US's bad debt during the Clinton and Obama eras.

I was also hearing stories that China was prepared to drop the US debt by passing it onto unwary 3rd parties at 10 cents for each dollar, to get some return on buying a bad product would be better than nothing after all. China also quite astutely negotiated access to the American markets as part of the debt restructuring of the US! 

I think what this is about is in part that Trump was trying to force Huawei to deliver backdoors as part of the rollout of 5G in the US. Aren't the NSA demanded/requested backdoors in modern telecommunications equipment an open secret now?

So I guess Huawei weren't wanting to play ball. After all look at South Korea where 5G has been available for some time now; where's the dodgy equipment outburst from the Koreans - there is none.

I think this is all about Trump using the one skill he has, which is surviving bad debt/ bankruptcy, you just need to look at his own financial dealings!

You need to go back at least 20 years or so that to see the signs that perhaps inform a particular story. 

All Trump is doing is entrenching in the only way available to him, (even H Clinton would have to have done the same also if she'd been elected).

Pretty good analysis/discussion though, I really enjoyed this particular vlog of yours. 

Moving on a bit Huawei happened to have had a head start in investing in future technologies. They should be allowed to reap the benefits of their prudent forward thinking. 

Doesn't Trump sound like a bully in the playground saying to a quietly confident person, you've made this newfangled toy and I want it, even if I didn't do anything in creating it - but by Trumps own self proclaimed rights, that it should be his, 

But your right it doesn't bode well for so called free markets, even in and for the west.

text:
One way you might like to look at this fiasco is the fear also could be targeted towards US manufacturers. For example; I just bought a P30 lite 3 days ago, I'm so happy with it over my old trust samsung note 4. Today I get this news, and now I am thinking I'm never buying a device that runs Android ever again in my life after being an avid android user through out my life. Because as you said I can't invest my hard earned money on a device that might end up in Huawei's situation. Yes today it is Huawei, tomorrow it might be samsung or any other company. So with the orange in the white house throwing tantrums like this, the only thing I can do is investing my money elsewhere. When I end up wearing my current device down, I'm going to look for the best device ''not running Android'' for my needs and budget and I'm going to buy it. Its google's loss, because as a customer I bought a device only to have my support stripped away literally days later. This fear will be with me forever, as a customer.

The sad part is that its not even Google's fault... If we have to point fingers, I guess we can point them at  the orange.
