They have a CEO/founder who belongs to that same country's Communist party and they also serve as a primary government contractor. They have numerous lawsuits against them dating back to the early 2000s that all involve misuse of data and infringement claims. China's primary objective is to dominate the global production of microchips and robotics by 2025 and one of their farthest reaching arms in those two fields is the state-run company Huawei. Allowing them to continue doing business with us is not in our best interests, politically or economically; short-term, their continued presence will save consumers money, but long-term they will collapse the entire telecommunications industry through market devaluation and the theft of intellectual property.

text:
This is all dirty tactics 101 from Trump and the Americans. You¬†called it, this is a hit job on Huawei. The US is just making things up as they go along to kill a superior competitor. How do we know? Well, when Trump asked Canada to arrest Meng in Vancouver, Trump already said he could look into it as part of the trade deal negotiations. That is another way of saying it is all BS about Huawei spying. 

Furthermore, it is no longer safe to do business with the States as long as Trump is still in power. In the case of smartphones, you are better off¬†making massive investment to develop your own OS, YouTube, ecosystem and what not. 

And if Trump wants to play hardball, China can easily ban Apple. And do you know how big of a hit is that? Apple generated US$52 billion of revenue last year from China and Hong Kong last year.

text:
Someone brought up a point that the existence of Samsung destroys the argument that the US kills foreign companies competing with the US ones. 
Have a look at this link https://www.samsung.com/global/ir/stock-information/ownership-structure/

If you look at Samsung‚Äôs ownership structure, you can see that Samsung has the majority of their stock held by foreign investors, more specifically people/organizations on Wall Street, like Citi group, Morgan Stanley etc.

The reason why Samsung isn‚Äôt banned and is allowed access to core technologies is obvious, it is basically American. Unlike Huawei, which is not a publicly traded company, and therefore is 100% privately owned by Chinese, consequently the US has literally 0 control over.

If you wonder why it is this way, I‚Äôll let you in on some history, after the 1997 Asian economic crisis, which was caused by the US to suppress economic growth in Asian countries like Korea, Samsung was broken into many subsidiaries and sold off to pay off their debt. For instance their heavy industrial department was sold to Volvo, Pharmaceutical department to Johnson Wax, LED to GE etc. after taking into account all the cross holding of interest, 55% of the current Samsung conglomerate is foreign, and mostly American. It was only after it is Americanized, it successfully globalized, whereas despite of its massive influence in Korea before the crisis, it was never truly global and never pierced into the most technologically advanced industries as one of the top contenders. 

If you look at globally successful companies in Asia, especially the biggest ones of a certain country/region like Mitsubishi of Japan, TSMC of Taiwan, Samsung of S Korea etc. they almost always had their controlling interest being American, or else they wouldn‚Äôt be allowed by the US to become anything significant. And those companies, like Samsung, also became American after a US caused economic crisis. Except in China, where the biggest companies are either state owned or Chinese owned and successfully survived multiple economic crisis basically unscathed. 

I‚Äôll let you figure of why the US is so afraid China and want to takedown Huawei at the risk of losing their hypocritical outlook of righteousness.

Huawei might not succeed, but it is a martyr, and it‚Äôs legacy will be significant and meaningful for any non-American own companies forward.

text: Good video Lew. To be honest, I am not worried about Huawei too much. Will they slow down their growth, yes. Will they shut down? No. The main reason Huawei can have a fight in this game is that the market in China is so big. 60% of the 4G stations on this planet are in China and this number may be even higher with 5G. Also the one of the largest smart phone market. I am from China and have been to US and Europe and I know the 4G coverage difference between the west and China, especially in rural area. So even if Huawei just serve the demand in China only, it will be just fine. And of couse, it got many EU and south east asia and middle east orders. The smartphone department is actually affacted least in this US bullying. The chip design tool you mentioned, there are some open source tool which is less efficient than the US ones but free to use. Other banned chips can be sourced else where too, but much less advanced of course. Some produced locally in China already. But with Huawei such a new big customer, the stock price of these local chip producers in China skyrocket these days. And it is possible they will invest more in R&D with the money from Huawei and become more advanced in the future. The key issue is the laptop department. Huawei laptop actually grows very quick these years. But without Intel or AMD. It is pretty dead for now. But there is very strong discussion that Huawei may release its own OS since no one will buy its phone without GOOGLE PLAY anyway. And at least the local apps in China will 100% sure adapt to this OS due to the government presure. In the oversea market, it is hard to say. Therefore, there may be laptop with kirin chips and Huawei OS in the future, just like the macs. You cant imagine the national sentiment in China about Huawei now. Their share in EU will go down, but their share in China will go further up.

text:
I‚Äôm an iPhone user, I prefer the os as I use it across multiple devices, but let me say this, I am absolutely devastated for Huawei. I‚Äôd go as far as saying that I hope they come back with a fight and continue with their innovation because we need them in the marketplace. To be 50% up in market share whilst knocking the likes of Apple down by about 30% and hitting Samsung along the way, not to mention the excellent Mate X to compete with Samsung‚Äôs failed Fold, AND their 5g technology, one would be hard pressed not to think there‚Äôs a conspiracy here. 

Samsung and Apple have been able to hike their prices and offer old tech for so many years and Huawei are a massive threat to these businesses. There‚Äôs more to this than meets the eye, and I see it as an equivalent to an assassination attempt because Huawei CAN innovate along with offering lower prices, and these big companies don‚Äôt like it. 

I have a lot of hope for Huawei, and if you‚Äôre a customer of theirs, please continue to support them and provide the biggest backlash you possibly can to show Trump and Google that the customer WANTS them in the marketplace. Losing Huawei will cost us customers dearly.

author: Martin Vasilev

text:
Attention retards that think they know everything... For one, this has nothing to do with trade since the US already doesn't do official business with Huawei. They were caught with their hands in the cookie jar.  People that say there isn't any proof haven't done any research at all. You really think Trump just pulled Huawei out of a hat full of the names of all the Chinese companies? I get that most of you don't like Trump and half of this channel is populated with sandies but even the most ardent Trump hater has to know better than that. 

As far as impact to American companies, there's some of that but it's justified if even a tenth of the things they have been accused of come out as true. Since they have all but refused to appear in court and plead their case... Again,  I implore you all, understand that this is ONE company out of thousands. There are reasons for these actions and this didn't just start with Trump either. If this were just about sticking it to China,  there are far better ways. 

Some of you might think that the demands made by the US Gov't to Huawei to continue to operate here were unfair,  maybe, but they could have complied. Same with China... look at our demands, they are literally fighting against being prohibited from stealing partner company's patents and processes. They are arguing against dropping their tariffs on our goods. They want to keep up their bans on our goods. They want to maintain their 5 to 1 trade imbalance with the US. Our position is basically, we'll drop our tarrifs and restrictions on your products if you drop yours on our products. China says NO! They are against fair and free trade with us, not us with them.

They would make billions just having their software on Huawei devices which do sell pretty well globally. On the other hand ,This whole bill is made to slow down Huawei(which is China's best way of making money in the US and it's far too advanced in the 5g territory .) so boosting Apple while keeping Huawei on the spot makes sense and the bill i think only bans hardware supplies from the US specifically . In Europe for example , the situation is completely different
author: Eleazar Moraru

text:
@Eleazar Moraru I don‚Äôt think you understand Apple‚Äôs business model. It‚Äôs based on hardware sales, not software. If they licence their OS to Huawei, it would cut into their own iPhone sales much worse than the lower numbers are now. And selling a license will NOT make ‚Äòbillions‚Äô for Apple at all. It would be far less than what they would lose in sales now. In addition, Huawei as a competitor will be less of a problem for them, if they can‚Äôt sell their phones with the full featured Android. They will simply decline in western markets. This might actually be much more beneficial for Apple.

You‚Äôre looking at it too much from a ‚Äòwhisful thinking‚Äô point of view, rather than a business one.

text:
To the Chinese communist party sympathizers, here's some stuff to think about. 

1) Huawei is a Chinese company. That is to say, it is a communist company, that is to say it is a branch of their totalitarian government. They do not operate like American/European/Free Market companies, and the issue of Spyware and threat from that is serious. They are a country with a completely different ideology that is at odds with the West. 

2) A Free Market is not totally free, the same way Free Speech doesn't mean you can threaten people. A Free Market is free, within THE RULES THAT EVERYONE ABIDES BY. If you engage in illegal activity, whether that is spying on a country or making dangerous products for the people without disclosing them, then you are NOT FREE from the law. On top of that, point to another market as free as America's. Just do it, I'm curious. And if you think they are being hypocrites and are too stupid to debate and argue within the nuance of complex systems, then what are you suggesting? Anarchy? No rules, every one is free to do what they want? Or are you just a pawn of ideology, liking things when they go your way and not when they dont? The same people shitting on Trump for blacklisting a suspicious Chinese company, a communist regime, most likely also cheered on the liberals for trying to impeach him on BS they made up about him working for the Russians. Which is it? Is Trump bad or good? Should the government protect against dangerous products, or should everything be pure capitalism, free markets with no regulation and no laws? And what's more important to you? Protecting the country and having principles against totalitarian nations, or getting a cheap fucking communist phone?

Starting new OS is not difficult and Huawei have recourses to make a great one, but no matter how good it is, if other brands wont adopt it, it will fail miserably (just like Windows Phone, which was pretty cool imo). What Lew didnt really mentioned here, is that china have a lot of other huge and still growing brands besides Huawei, and while Huawei is the biggest and have closer ties to chinese government,  others are not too far off. Event like this will send a very clear message to those brands, nationalist governed monopoly is not to be trusted. If im Xiaomi, i profit from this short term, but long term i might get shafted too. If those other brands reach out to each other and work cross party together, then eventually there surely can be a new os possible. text:
Join me in the google ban by doing the following:
Forget Play store - Use APK supported sites
Forget Gmail - Go for the hundreds of other email services
Forget Google Maps - https://blogs.systweak.com/5-best-google-maps-alternatives/
Forget Chrome - Use chromium based browsers
Forget youtube - https://twitgoo.com/best-youtube-alternatives/


Android users particularly those in China have been using their Android devices happily without Google, we can too.


I'm interested to see what youtube tech reviewers will do, join the ban or continue to support Apple :-D


Edit: Some things to respond to this video:
- Google was banned in China because they didn't want to follow Chinese laws.
- Google's ban on Huawei is a direct result of government intervention, which means that they too are government controlled!
- If open source fans desert Google they will desert youtube, which means more people unsubscribing from your channel.

text:
Funny it seems like Trump is playing hard ball with these actions. You think though, his success in business was individual transactions that you negotiate. You get in a room, and there is a negotiation with a winner and a loser.. You think these kind interactions, you might have leverage on Steel so you can fuck the Chinese on Steel, but because this dynamic is a perpetual relationship with disparate contextual leverage, it means the Chinese will exercise leverage someplace else..   So you end up with a tit for tat escalation. Diplomacy kind of seems different. 

It's funny with powerful people, often the way humans work is we learn conventions and then over generations we forget the reasons for the conventions because we never needed to learn why, and Trump's poker agression in diplomacy you wondered what would happen because it seemed to bear fruit but the politicians that went before him were all exceptionally clever men and women and the US have always had the economic leverage to exercise so why weren't they that agressive historically?

text:
I would argue that customer confidence is shot in everything that the US supplies. If Trump can do this to Huawei overnight, who is to say he might get into a dispute with South Korea next month over the way they are dealing with North Korea and enlist Samsung on their blacklist as well?
Also, Huawei already paid Google to license Android. Before that license expires, Huawei has the right to use a product they paid for. Otherwise, Huawei can take this up in court and argue that a US company simply took their money and ran.


At the end of the day, national security is not an excuse that should be thrown around without some thought first. Using this excuse recklessly can undermine US credibility. If Huawei really is a threat, just show us the evidence.

text:
Im a network engineer by trade and i can say that huawei are a global leader with confidence,  you judt watcged the same video as me and heard that cisco have mkre back doors? But its ok as its a US company? 

Why would they get involved when shit like this happens? Its not within their interest and if china put on lressure they are international so they can relocate and cut ties? 

I understand the concerns for 5G, however many cluntries and companies will utilise huawei in one form or anouther, with many western countires excluding them from the core network in the event of a chinese goverment forced shutdown or network breech etc...

Its a huge shame tbh... and the militsry network is fully distant from the lrivate sector, ofcourse it intergrates to an extent.. but the encryption it recieves end to end is to this day still not cracked... its tit for tat at the end of the day but when it all settles we need them more than they need us... asia is leaps and bounds ahead in terms of infrastructure and network capabilities and there are far more extensive and exploitative ways to spy and hack then to use handsets.....

Say what you want but a global leader in communication gone? I dont think people understand the consequences... phone services, data centres, cloud computing, emergency service networks etc etc all have huawei in them somewhere... 

As lew said it could go bad and its gonna sting... a lot... or we could see positive and welcome change.. im all for innovation and change. 

Until i see evidence of these allogations.. definitive proof of security risks then in all for huawei, just seems odd that reelection is coming up and the US economy is slowing down? Nice coincidence.. not to me tion the iran situation? 

America time and time again use the eaat and war as a means for reelection.. look at vietnam, president after president used it as a means for personal gain..  

Politics should never stand in the way of science in terms of pure innovation for the good of humanity.. obviously there are moral limits i.e genetics testing etc but you get my point.

The essence of what the west stands for is under threat... freedom.. we cant even choose to abort children anymore let alone what phone we want and more..

text: Master Sherpa you do realize the majority of Samsung‚Äôs stake is held by American right? If I remember correctly, Samsung is 50%~60% American.
author: Ë∞¢ÊòäÂ§©

text:
Master Sherpa https://www.samsung.com/global/ir/stock-information/ownership-structure/
If you look at Samsung‚Äôs ownership structure, you can see that Samsung has the majority of their stock held by foreign investors, more specifically people/organizations on Wall Street, like Citi group, Morgan Stanley etc.
The reason why Samsung isn‚Äôt banned and is allowed access to core technologies is obvious, it is basically American. Unlike Huawei, which is not a publicly traded company, and therefore is 100% privately owned by Chinese, consequently the US has literally 0 control over.
If you wonder why it is this way, I‚Äôll let you in on some history, after the 1997 Asian economic crisis, which was caused by the US to suppress economic growth in Asian countries like Korea, Samsung was broken into many subsidiaries and sold off to pay off their debt. For instance their heavy industrial department was sold to Volvo, Pharmaceutical department to Johnson Wax, LED to GE etc. after taking into account all the cross holding of interest, 55% of the current Samsung conglomerate is foreign, and mostly American. It was only after it is Americanized, it successfully globalized, whereas despite of its massive influence in Korea before the crisis, it was never truly global and never pierced into the most technologically advanced industries as one of the top contenders. 
If you look at globally successful companies in Asia, especially the biggest ones of a certain country/region like Mitsubishi of Japan, TSMC of Taiwan, Samsung of S Korea etc. they almost always had their controlling interest being American, or else they wouldn‚Äôt be allowed by the US to become anything significant. And those companies, like Samsung, also became American after a US caused economic crisis. Except in China, where the biggest companies are either state owned or Chinese owned and successfully survived multiple economic crisis basically unscathed. 
I‚Äôll let you figure of why the US is so afraid China and want to takedown Huawei at the risk of losing their hypocritical outlook of righteousness.

@Slaik First of all, the Chinese follow a communist regime. Have you experienced the atrocious communist ideology yourself?  Commies are different, to put it lightly. For them to act like they act is understandable, given their political regime. But what about the rest of us? Are we still all fucking morons in it for ourselves, because we all act like we're not (but we all know we are), like we're all so civilized in comparison. 

Don't get me wrong, I have worked under Huawei, I have seen first hand the negatives but also the positives. You have no fucking idea how dedicated and professional they are, especially in the telecom branch, and that's why they are #1. That's why every other technology by comparison feels like it belongs in the Stone age. I wonder if Ericsson or Nokia will ever beat them now. But don't get it twisted, they dont do it out of benevolence. Like any other company, they provide services for their own benefit, and since China is a communist country, that means it is in the benefit of the country. And it's because they're communists that they have such strict security policies (and I have experienced them fully). They're in it for themselves, but at least their political ideology reflects that, which can't be said about the rest of us.

The US spies and destroys whatever it wants, but it pretends is the angel or freedom and god knows what else. The US are the definition of hypocrisy.

I don't have any horse in this race, humanity is a lost cause and the majority of the people can't sleep at night if they don't exercise their right of free speech, ending up spewing absolute garbage. It is still so unfortunate to see how privileged the US appears in comparison to China and Russia. We're already being spied by Google, we don't want the Chinese aswell. Why people behave like this is beyond me.

And to be fair, Google can suck my cock. They can  be all gay up there with Trump if that shit stays inside the US, but don't bring that shit outside like the rest of the fucking world cares about the US spying drama.
